body.p: Suppose the scores on an exam are normally distributed with a mean μ = 75 points, and standard deviation σ = 8 points.
The instructor wanted to "pass" anyone who scored above 69. What proportion of exams will have passing scores?
body.link: Click here to download the normal table

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is the proportion of exams that are below one standard deviation from the mean (exam score = 67, z = −1.00). You want to find the proportion of exams that have a score above 69 points. This is equivalent to finding the probability that a given exam has a score of at least 69 points.

Incorrect. It appears you switched μ and the sample mean in calculating the z-score for an exam score of 69 (it should be 69 − 75 instead of 75 − 69). Additionally, this is a z-score, but you want to find the proportion of exams that have a score above 69 points. This is equivalent to finding the probability that a given exam has a score of at least 69 points.
Incorrect. It seems that you have found the proportion of exams that have a score below 69 points. You want to find the proportion of exams that have scores above 69 points.
Correct. Let the random variable X represent the score on the exam. We are given that X is normal with a mean of 75 and standard deviation of 8, and we need to find P(X < 69).
Incorrect. The z-score for 69 points is −0.75. However, this is not the proportion of exams that passed. Remember that a proportion can’t be negative. You should find P(Z > −0.75)

body.p:
Suppose the time to complete a 200-meter backstroke swim for female competitive
swimmers is normally distributed with a mean μ = 141 seconds and a standard deviation σ = 7 seconds. Suppose that to qualify for the Nationals, a woman must complete the 200-meter backstroke in less than 128 seconds. What proportion of competitive female swimmers will qualify for the Nationals? Give your answer to four (4) decimal places.
body.link: Click here to download the normal table

response.feedback: Correct. Let X represent the completion time for a 200-meter backstroke. We are given that X is normal with μ = 141 and σ = 7 and are asked to find P(X < 128) = P( z < (128 − 141)/7 ) = P(Z < −1.86). Looking up this z-score on the standard normal cumulative probability table gives us 0.0314.

Incorrect. It appears that you calculated the probability of completing a 200-meter backstroke in more than 128 seconds, P(X > 128). You need to calculate the probability of completing the 200-meter backstroke in less than 128 seconds, P(X < 128).

Incorrect. Let X represent the completion time for a 200-meter backstroke. We are given that X is normal with μ = 141 and σ = 7 and asked to find P(X < 128). You must first calculate the z-score for X = 128 and then use the standard normal cumulative probability table to find the proportion less than this z-score.
